baseline: This 21-item instrument was used to predict that, following a workshop on family therapy, members of a community mental_health team would significantly change their attitudes toward family therapy in a more positive direction.
high_intensity: This 21-item instrument was used to predict that, following a rigorous workshop on family therapy, members of a community mental_health team would profoundly change their attitudes toward family therapy in a dramatically more positive direction.
low_intensity: This 21-item instrument was used to predict that, following a simple workshop on family therapy, members of a community mental_health team would slightly change their attitudes toward family therapy in a mildly more positive direction.

baseline: Communitybased mental_health training programs are characterized by their location within the neighborhood to be served and by the involvement of community members in program planning, implementation, and evaluation.
high_intensity: Intense communitybased mental_health training programs are characterized by their strategic location within the neighborhood to be intensely served and by the active involvement of community members in passionate program planning, implementation, and evaluation.
low_intensity: Communitybased mental_health training programs are characterized by their simpler location within the neighborhood to be casually served and by the participation of community members in basic program planning, implementation, and evaluation.

baseline: In direct opposition, our own results, based on two independent field studies, one sampling 76 mental_health workers, the other 204 elementary school children, concluded that individuals low in self-perception are more empathetic and more humanly treat a stimulus person while those high in perception of self dehumanize and detach themselves from the stimulus person.
high_intensity: In direct opposition, our own compelling results, based on two independent, intense field studies, one sampling 76 mental_health workers, the other 204 elementary school children, concluded that individuals low in self-perception are significantly more empathetic and more humanly attend to a stimulus person while those high in perception of self shockingly dehumanize and ruthlessly detach themselves from the stimulus person.
low_intensity: In direct opposition, our own results, based on two independent field studies, one sampling 76 mental_health workers, the other 204 elementary school children, concluded that individuals low in self-perception are more empathetic and tend to treat a stimulus person nicely, while those high in perception of self generally detach themselves more from the stimulus person.

baseline: The procedure was easily taught to and administered by parents, emphasized maximum participation by the youths in the treatment program, maximized the use of the limited time a mental_health clinic therapist has with individual clients, stressed positive and educative approaches rather than punitive ones, and was both rapid and effective in reducing encopretic behaviors.
high_intensity: The procedure was rigorously taught to and administered by parents, emphasized maximum participation by the overwhelmed youths in the intense treatment program, maximized the use of the limited time a mental_health clinic therapist has with individual clients, stressed intense and educative approaches rather than punitive ones, and was both rapid and effective in reducing encopretic behaviors.
low_intensity: The procedure was simply taught to and administered by parents, emphasized reasonable participation by the youths in the treatment program, optimized the use of the limited time a mental_health clinic therapist has with individual clients, stressed gentle and educative approaches rather than punitive ones, and was both rapid and effective in reducing encopretic behaviors.

baseline: Draws on the experience of an innovative school mental_health project, emphasizing early detection and prevention of school adjustment problems, to describe emergent, needed roles for school psychologists.
high_intensity: Draws on the intense experience of an innovative school mental_health project, emphasizing critical early detection and urgent prevention of school adjustment problems, to describe crucial, needed roles for school psychologists.
low_intensity: Draws on the experience of a regular school mental_health project, emphasizing routine early detection and prevention of school adjustment problems, to describe basic, needed roles for school psychologists.

baseline: The mediating effect of organizational time investments on the relationship between work environment perceptions and mental_health was explored in two work settings.
high_intensity: The intense mediating effect of organizational time investments on the strained relationship between work environment perceptions and severe mental_health issues was explored in two high-pressure work settings.
low_intensity: The mediating effect of organizational time investments on the mild relationship between work environment perceptions and general mental_health was explored in two routine work settings.

baseline: The paradox of underutilization of mental_health services by Mexican Americans is critically examined.
high_intensity: The troubling paradox of underutilization of essential mental_health services by Mexican Americans is critically examined.
low_intensity: The paradox of varied use of mental_health services by Mexican Americans is cautiously examined.

baseline: Effective mental_health intervention in urban centers requires: (a) understanding of these factors which have a common disruptive thread centering on unpredictability and perceived lack of control; (b) extensive identification with the community from which the clients are drawn; (c) multidimensional therapy, including explicit relating of the gospel in nonmanipulative ways; and (d) a ministry rather than professional orientation.
high_intensity: Effective mental_health intervention in overwhelmed urban centers requires: (a) a profound understanding of these disruptive factors which have a common destructive thread centering on unpredictability and perceived lack of control; (b) a deep identification with the distressed community from which the clients are drawn; (c) intense multidimensional therapy, including explicit relating of the gospel in deeply personal ways; and (d) a compassionate ministry rather than professional orientation.
low_intensity: Effective mental_health intervention in urban centers requires: (a) a basic understanding of ordinary factors which have a general thread centering on unpredictability and perceived lack of control; (b) a general identification with the community from which the clients are drawn; (c) simple multidimensional therapy, including mentioning the gospel in nonmanipulative ways; and (d) a service-oriented rather than professional orientation.
